name: Albert Kennedy Trust
shortDescription: Support for LGBT young people in crisis
description:
The Albert Kennedy Trust supports lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans homeless young people in crisis. Every day we deal with the effects homelessness can have on young people's lives. We have offices in London, Manchester and Newcastle. The Albert Kennedy Trust is here to help you if you are:

 - Up to the age of 25
 - Are (or think you might be) Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, or Trans
 - Homeless or living in crisis
 - Living in a violent , hostile or abusive home
donationDescription:
Every Donation to AKT delivers help where it's most needed.

The numbers of young people contacting us increases year on year and it is important in increase our donations at the same rate.
itemsDonationDescription:
Items can be delivered to the following address, but please call ahead on 0161 228 3308 to arrange.

The Albert Kennedy Trust
5 Oak Street, Northern Quarter
Manchester M4 5JD

name: Befrienders
shortDescription: Food bank
description: Food bank provided at the Methodist Central Hall on Mondays and Wednesday from 14:00-16:00

name: Audacious A-Teams
shortDescription: Outreach teams providing food and support for homeless people and sex workers. Also access to personal items including baby items and food parcels.
description: !Audacious A-Teams are a team of people that help and reach out to the homeless and the vulnerable in Manchester city centre. A-Teams are !Audacious Church on legs, reaching out to the homeless and vulnerable people of Manchester every Thursday evening at the church and on the other six evenings of the week the team is out on the streets to give support . Each and every Thursday we provide a hot meal and support within the church. This support includes access to a clothing bank, a chiropody service and a hairdresser.
itemsDonationDescription: Items can be collected locally from within the Greater Manchester area. Please contact Julian Wolstencroft on 0161 830 7000 or julianwolstencroft@audaciouschurch.com to arrange.

name: Stretford Foodbank
shortDescription: Foodbank operating in Trafford
description: Our foodbank is part of The Trussell Trust’s network of 428 foodbanks, working to tackle food poverty and hunger in our local communities, as well as across the UK. We operate by referral. We work with many local agencies that work with the public. All our partnering agencies hold vouchers and can refer people to the foodbank when they identify a genuine need.
donationDescription: Our foodbank is run by local people for local people – we rely on the community’s support to ensure we can continue to stop people going hungry. Can you invest in the future of our project and help us provide much-needed support to people in crisis in our community?
itemsDonationDescription:
Our foodbank relies on your goodwill and support.

Over 90% of the food distributed by foodbanks in The Trussell Trust network is donated by the public – that’s why your food donations are absolutely vital to our ability to give everyone referred to us a balanced and nutritious three day supply of food.

name: Open Door Greater Manchester
shortDescription: helping people with a need
description: feeding clothing and trying to house homeless  we provide council for drugs ,alcohol ,abuse and mental health we will also aid foodbanks and sign post people to other charities or orgs
itemsDonationDescription: Currently only able to accept sleeping bags and bedding as well as men's clothes and shoes. Please contact Robert Lee on 07785374673 to arrange delivery of the items.

name: Threshold
shortDescription: Threshold are a housing, advice and support charity with operations across Greater Manchester and are part of the New Charter Group.
description: Threshold have been working to support vulnerable people to achieve greater independence and wellbeing for decades.

name: Food4All@Apostles

description: We offer a weekly seated hot homecooked meal, in a friendly, warm environment. Subject to availabilty we can offer clothing and food parcels. We also provide signposting to available services.

name: The Bond Board
shortDescription: The Bond Board is a homeless charity that enables people to access private rented accommodation.
description: We provide bonds that replace the need for a cash deposit in Bolton and Rochdale.

name: Citizens Advice Manchester

We also have an extensive outreach service with sessions across the city, including at Cheetham Hill Advice Centre, along with our telephone advice and email advice services, which can be accessed through our website.

name: Greater Manchester Community Chaplaincy
shortDescription: Help for ex-offenders
description: GMCC is a charity that exists to help people who have been in prison. Most people are aware of the impact of crime on families and communities and also of the high percentage of reoffending among those who go to prison as a result.
donationDescription: We help those who have been in prison and are ready for a fresh start to find the way to begin and the support to continue. We work with people of any faith or none.

name: Infinity Initiatives
shortDescription: Infinity Initiatives support vulnerable individuals and families who have needs such as homelessness, substance abuse, debt, isolation and offending.
description: Infinity Initiatives also undertake preventative work in schools and in the community.

name: Bury Baptist Church

description: Bury Baptist Church has a membership of over 100 people.

name: Tameside Citizens Advice Bureau

description: The main advice provision can be located at the council offices in Ashton whilst other advice surgeries are available in other areas of the borough and can be found at https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/about-us/how-we-provide-advice/advice/search-for-your-local-citizens-advice/local-citizens-advice-details/?serialnumber=100476

name: St Ann's Hospice
shortDescription: St Ann’s Hospice is Greater Manchester’s largest hospice.
description: We care for patients from our Heald Green, Little Hulton and Neil Cliffe Centre sites, as well as in their own homes and communities.

name: Joint Veteran Alliance
shortDescription: Support for veterans experiencing homelessness.
description: We support veterans through the transition from being homeless to being re-housed. We make applications for training courses to assist with future employment and assist in making applications for employment.  We refer to various agencies in respect of Drug and Alcohol abuse and issues resulting from conflicts undertaken in their service such as PTSD, Combat Stress and Mental Health, including to Royal British Legion and SSAFA.
itemsDonationDescription: Items not currently needed.

name: Lifeshare
shortDescription: Assistance and support for people facing homelessness, exploitation and poverty.
description: We offer practical assistance, support and information to people at risk and in need. We have a drop in on Tuesday and Friday for young people from 16-25. Our weekend breakfast project for over 18s supplies clothes, bedding and showers at our Dantzic St centre, and there is hairdressers, GPs and podiatrists at Wellbeing clinic on the last Sunday of each month (limited prescribing).
donationDescription: Donations are essential for activities such as our Weekend Breakfast Project and Christmas Project.

name: Bury Red Door
shortDescription: Homeless centre in Bury
description: Bury Red door provides a welcoming and safe space for homeless people and those experiencing hardship.

name: Talk To Frank
shortDescription: Online service providing information on drugs and addiction help
description: FRANK is a national drug education service jointly established by the Department of Health and Home Office of the British government in 2003.

name: Bury Christian Fellowship
shortDescription: Religious organisation
description: Bury Christian Fellowship is a Christian Group providing practical assistance and counselling.

name: MASH; Manchester Action on Street Health
shortDescription: Female sex worker support.
description:
Manchester Action on Street Health (MASH) provides support to women who sex work from across Greater Manchester.

We offer non-judgmental support to women who sex work on the street, in saunas and as escorts. Support is provided through an outreach van, outreach into saunas, a City Centre Drop-In and the website.

The sauna outreach: The Sexual Health Nurse visits a number of saunas (massage parlours) around Manchester and Bury to offer sexual health screening, treatment and information about contraception.

MASH is in a grey building with a large billboard on one side and a red post box near the front door. It is located on the right hand side of Fairfield Street after you walk under the railway bridges when walking from Piccadilly Station. Please press the buzzer to gain entry.

name: Military Veterans' Service
shortDescription: Mental health support to ex-service personnel.
description: We provide mental health support to ex-service personnel for conditions including depression, alcohol and substance misuse, anger problems and post-traumatic stress disorder.

name: Caritas Diocese of Salford
shortDescription: Social welfare charity serving in-need children & adults in Greater Manchester & East Lancashire.
description: Our purpose is to help the most vulnerable children, young people and adults in our communities to transform their lives and fulfil their potential. Caritas means 'love for humanity'. 130 years serving those in need in Greater Manchester & Lancashire.

name: Trafford South Foodbank
shortDescription: Foodbank under the Trussell Trust serving communities in South Trafford
description: The Foodbank Network was founded in 2004 after four years of developing the original foodbank based in Salisbury. Since then The Trussell Trust has helped communities work together to launch foodbanks nationwide in a wide range of towns and cities. In 2016/17, The Trussell Trust’s Foodbank Network provided 1,182,954 three-day emergency food supplies and support to UK people in crisis. Of these, over 430,000 went to children.

name: Salford UCRC
shortDescription: SUCRC offers practical solutions to the issues local people face, such as advice on benefits, links to credit unions and informal education sessions.
description:
Salford Unemployed and Community Resource Centre was established in 1980, at a time when Britain was blighted with job losses and mass unemployment.

It continues its work today, campaigning, supporting, advising and representing unemployed and employed people. Working with some of the most vulnerable people in society, the Centre is regarded locally as the fourth emergency service.

name: Recycling Lives
shortDescription: Anyone can become homeless. Residents have joined Recycling Lives from homeless shelters, prisons and the armed forces. Recycling Lives offers life-changing opportunities to those facing an uncertain future.
description:
The award-winning Recycling Lives social welfare charity
helps homeless and vulnerable people to get back on their
feet through a six-stage programe of training, work
experience and support. A range of social enterprise activities
reward Residents for their achievements with employment
opportunities.

name: Nacro Housing - Manchester
shortDescription: Accomodation and support regaining independence
description: Nacro Housing provides accommodation and advice to those who need short term support to regain their independence. To access this service you need to be 16-64, homeless, single, have a history of offending or at risk of offending, and in need of housing related support.
donationDescription: Your donations help us reduce crime by changing lives and offering hope to communities and individuals across England and Wales. Making an online donation is a simple and secure way of giving to Nacro.

name: Sanctuary Supported Living - Manchester
shortDescription: We provide care, supported living services and accommodation across England - helping people to live independently.
description: We are a national provider of care, support and housing for individuals with mental health needs, learning and physical disabilities, those who have experienced homelessness and young people.

name: People First Housing Association
shortDescription: Community-based, tenant-led housing association
description: People First assist more than 100 households and employ around 20 staff through our support and befriending services. Primarily we provide floating support across the city of Manchester to vulnerable people with mental health issues who are at risk of losing their accommodation and/or need short term support to help them maintain independence. We also provide resettlement support to people who have experienced issues with alcohol, drug use, homelessness and/or offending/reoffending to establish their independence in their own home.

name: RISE Manchester
shortDescription: Drug and alcohol dependency help
description: We are a leading charity providing treatment and support to over 60,000 vulnerable people in England and Wales every day. We champion people who have faced hardships like abuse, homelessness and addiction, and empower them to lead the lives they want, on their terms.

addresses.street: Zion Community Resource Centre, 339 Stretford Road

name: Riverside - Manchester
shortDescription: Transforming lives and revitalising neighbourhoods
description:
Our supported housing services and schemes combine accommodation with support. They are designed to meet the needs of particular groups, such as young people , addiction issues ,ex-offenders, people experiencing homeless for the first time or on multiple occasions.

Some schemes and services are designed for people who need support to live independently. Others are short-term and designed to help people acquire the emotional and practical skills needed to move on into more mainstream housing.

name: Salford Housing Options
shortDescription: Free housing advice
description: Salford Housing Options offers a free advice service delivered by Salix Homes on behalf of the city council on matters such as education, training and employment, renting from private landlords, renting from a housing association, problems with your landlord, threat of eviction, mortgage arrears, repossession and homelessness. We can provide emergency accommodation.

name: Samaritans
shortDescription: Confidential advice service
description: Talk to us any time you like, in your own way, and off the record – about whatever’s getting to you. You don’t have to be suicidal.

name: Shelter
shortDescription: The housing and homelessness charity
description: Shelter gives practical housing advice and support online, in person and by phone. Our expert advisers give free, confidential advice and information for anyone with housing, debt, welfare benefit advice and support needs.
donationDescription: For every £1 you donate, 79p goes towards helping people struggling with bad housing and homelessness. And for every £1 we spend on fundraising, we raise another £3.80 to put back into our services.

name: St Mary's Sexual Assault Referral Centre
shortDescription: St Mary's Centre provides a range of services for anyone who has been raped or sexually assaulted
description:
St Mary's Sexual Assault Referral Centre (SARC) provides a comprehensive and co-ordinated forensic, counselling and aftercare service to men, women and children living in the Greater Manchester and Cheshire area who have experienced rape or sexual assault, whether this has happened recently or in the past.

Our on-call advice and information service operates out of hours 24/7: call 061 276 6515

name: Bolton Young Persons Housing Scheme
shortDescription: BYPHS supports young people aged 16 - 25. We prevent homelessness and enable independent living.
description: Bolton Young Persons Housing Scheme is a registered charity (1064698) providing temporary supported accommodation to people aged 16-25 in Bolton. We support young people who are homeless with support needs by offering accommodation, emotional and practical help with the aim of enabling independent living. We currently provide 8 different services.

name: Streets Ahead
shortDescription: Food and clothing for Manchester's homeless
description: Chadderton based Volunteers helping to provide food & clothing to the Homeless of Manchester.

name: Salford Raising and Giving (RAG)
shortDescription: Charity fundraising society at the University of Salford, Manchester.
description: We are a student-led society at the University of Salford with the main aim of raising and giving to charity. Along with organising fundraising events for a variety of different charities, we have also recently started a Help the Homeless campaign, with the main aim of providing resources, necessary items and friendly faces to the homeless people of Manchester and Salford, both on the streets and at food banks and street kitchens.

name: The vow team
shortDescription: Weekly soup kitchen.
description: The vow team run a soup kitchen from 7-9pm on Friday's at Cathedral Gardens.

name: Urban Village Medical Practice
shortDescription: Primary care for homeless people
description: Urban Village Medical Practice is the main provider of primary health care to homeless people in Manchester.
areaServiced: Manchester city centre, Ancoats and surrounding areas

name: Wellspring Community Church
shortDescription: Foodbank
description: Foodbank provided on Thursdays from 13:30-14:30 and by appointment, referral needed.

name: New Hope
shortDescription: New Hope is a charity established by the Church of Nazarene in 2011 to give bespoke support.
description:
We support people  tackling various issues, from homelessness to poor education, lack of social skills or recovery from drug or alcohol addiction. 

New Hope is run mostly by volunteers who bring a wide variety of skills and their own life experience, many of whom are from a social services/teaching background.

New Hope runs a tailor made individual package to suit each member's needs, which usually gives each client a minimum of 6 months with us.

name: The Men's Room
shortDescription: Working creatively with men up to the age of 30
description: The Men's Room is an arts and social charity that works creatively with disempowered men aged 18-30, supporting male sex workers, homeless men and men involved in the criminal justice system. We run creative sessions including drama, music, photography, creative writing, film making and visual arts. We also offer drop in and personalised one-to-one support, as well as outreach.
donationDescription:
The Men's Room currently delivers all it does on the equivalent of 2 Full Time staff per week.
We need to increase capacity of the organisation, but also we need to fund incentives to secure sustained involvement from the young men we support.
Your donations make a real difference!
itemsDonationDescription: Please contact us for further details.  We appreciate items to be dropped off, but we can collect in city centre.

name: Reach Out to the Community
shortDescription: Reach Out to the Community support people struggling with the most basic of needs: food and shelter.
description:
Reach Out to the Community focuses on two groups: rough sleepers in and around the Chorlton area of Greater Manchester, and local individuals and families who are in food poverty.
Services include the provision of survival supplies, clothing and practical help to the homeless, and making food parcels available to those whose circumstances mean they are unable to afford to eat properly.

ROC was founded in 2016 by Becky and Steph. Their secular remit is simple: to provide practical help for people in need, with kindness, compassion, and without judgement.

ROC works in partnership with many other Manchester-based organisations and individuals.
itemsDonationDescription: Items can be dropped off at Elliott's Greengrocers in Chorlton Precinct, between 7:30am and 4:30pm Monday to Saturday.

name: St Ann's Church
shortDescription: St Ann's church provides an early hours 'Morning Hours' drop in for those who are street homeless.
description:
St Ann's church provides a safe-space for the street homeless who are moved out of shop doorways in the early hours. In addition to providing a safe-space, 
They also hold an annual commemoration service to remember members of the homeless community who have died and for those who are homeless to remember friends and family members who have died. 
The church also hosts exhibitions of art created by people who are homeless

name: Student action MSU
shortDescription: Student Action UOM Outreach.
description:
Student Action of University of Manchester's student's union are running a new homeless outreach. 

In partnership with Change4Good of Mancunian Way, we are aligning our projects with the Manchester Charter for Homeless people and no longer giving out food or drinks. 

Instead we are working towards building relationships with homeless people, supporting them to make positive decisions in their lives and sign post them to the various professioal organisations who can really help them to make important changes and overcome barriers.
donationDescription: We weclome any training that grassroots and professional organisations can offer us to make what we do the best for homeless people.

name: Booth Centre
shortDescription: Day centre offering activities, advice and support to homeless people.
description:
The Booth Centre is here to bring about positive change in the lives of people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, and help them plan for and realise a better future. ​
We do this by providing a range of activities to help people rebuild their confidence and learn new skills while having fun. We run art, educational and job related
sessions daily with a free breakfast and lunch for all who attend. Advice is also available for those attending the service and we will support people to find accommodation, claim benefits, obtain ID and referrals to other services.
donationDescription: Donations enable us to provide invaluable support to vulnerable people when they need it most. Homeless people receive everything, including food and drinks, free of charge.
itemsDonationDescription: www.boothcentre.org.uk/donate-goods

name: Bury Rough Sleepers
shortDescription: We aim to ensure that no-one will sleep rough on the streets of Bury.
description:
Through dedicated drop-in sessions, clear referral routes, and robust outreach services, we aim to provide a rapid response to ensure appropriate solutions to rough sleeping are identified, and to offer person-centred support through joint working.

You can help by letting us know about anyone you think may be rough sleeping by completing this [form](https://calicohomes.org.uk/care-support/for-the-homeless/bury-rough-sleepers/).
telephone: Freephone referral line 08001692407 (ext 6311) or Text 07813 459 832 or 01282 686 311 (Out of hours)

name: Great Places Housing Group
shortDescription: Great Places is a housing association that provides over 16,000 high-quality homes in 30 council areas across the north west and beyond.
description: We also provide 1,500 supported housing units for vulnerable people including teenage parents and people with drug or alcohol problems, or mental health issues.

name: Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council
shortDescription: Council for the metropolitan borough of Tameside.
description: Our Customer Service Centre is located in Clarence Arcade, Stamford Street, Ashton-under-Lyne, OL6 7PT. 0161 342 8355.

shortDescription: General advice for housing issues
description: Help and support to prevent homelessness - working with landlords to resolve issues, help with court appeals, and negotiate extending lodging arrangements. We also make referrals and assist in any way to avoid the loss of a home.

addresses.street: Homeless Welfare, Ground Floor, Town Hall, Victoria Square

name: Salvation Army (Oldham)
shortDescription: Drop-in centre for homeless people every Friday, offering hot meals.
description: Drinks, snacks, newspapers and board games, a listening ear and someone to talk to for those in need of support, including on housing. We accept referrals for food parcels from outside agencies
itemsDonationDescription:
Childrens toys and games, food and drink, materials for activities.

Donations can be dropped off on Wednesdays 12pm - 2.30pm and Fridays 11am - 1pm. The building is also open at other ad hoc times - please call 01616246550 to check other times.

name: Urban Outreach Bolton
shortDescription: A Christian charity providing holistic, person-centered approach to support with disadvantaged, vulnerable and complex adults and young people.
description:
We work in four main areas - Offender support, Complex needs and homelessness, Children and families, Food and cold weather provision. 

Our Bolton Lunches run during the summer holidays providing 1500 free packed lunches each day to children and young people on low income that would usually receive free school meals. 

Christmas Dinner on Jesus provides 1200 hampers for individuals and families containing everything they need for a traditional Christmas dinner.
 
Eves Space supports female offenders at risk of re-offending through one-to-one support and group work.

Friends of Fun Food offers cooking and meal planning support.

RUNA (Remember Ur Not Alone) work with children that run away from home. We undertake joint visits with the police and families to support and address the issues that caused the child to run away.
 
Store House provides weekly food parcels for those in need, either collected or delivered.
 
Street Life helps homeless people find accommodation and provide on-going support to help clients sustain their tenancies. This is volunteer support based.

Support First helps vulnerable adults with a range of social and lifestyle needs after repeatedly using the emergency services. (More aimed at complex needs of individuals rather than homelessness).

Winter Watch provides up to 90 homeless people with food, clothing, showers and advice on weekend evening from January through to March.

name: First Choice Homes Oldham
shortDescription: Preventing homelessness, as well as assisting people searching for a home.
description: We work with a number of agencies to prevent homelessness and, to assist people to access private rented sector for accommodation. We offer advice for those who are homeless or may become homeless on a range of topics including, domestic abuse, mortgage or rent arrears, supported accommodation and Keyring Floating Support Service. We also offer advice when people have been asked to leave by family or friends or have been evicted.

name: Inspiring Change Manchester
shortDescription: Support for people with multiple needs
description: An online / telephone / postal referral service enabling access to various support organisations. Led by Shelter, Inspiring Change Manchester is a new and innovative approach to supporting those with multiple needs. This eight-year programme, funded through Big Lottery Fund’s £112m fulfilling lives project, has been designed and developed with service users to meet the diverse requirements of people with a variety of complex needs (including a history of problem drug and alcohol use, mental health or emotional well-being issues, accommodation problems and offending).

name: Endeavour Project (Previously Paws for Kids)
shortDescription: A unique charity supporting women, children and their pets escape from a life of violence and abuse to a better and caring future.
description:
We offer services for women, men, vulnerable young adults, children and their pets escaping and recovering from Domestic Abuse in Bolton.

We also offer safety planning and advise for people recovering from Domestic Abuse and violence.

In addition to services mentioned, we also offer a Pet Fostering service, for pets belonging to victims needing temporary accommodation.  Please visit [our page](http://www.pawsforkids.org.uk/pets-fostering.html) for more information.

name: Irwell Valley Housing Association
shortDescription: Manchester based housing association
description:
Our aim as an award winning housing association is to create fantastic places to live, work and enjoy life.

We operate an extended telephone service on Wednesday evenings until 6:30pm.

name: Lifeline
shortDescription: Lifeline Eclypse offers support and treatment for young people using drugs.
description: Drug services for young people, including Spice users.

name: New Life Church
shortDescription: New Life Church are part of the Tameside East Foodbank group.
description: New Life Church provide a meal for those experiencing homelessness and/or isolation. More details can be found at http://www.newlifetameside.org.uk/

name: Tameside Armed Services Community
shortDescription:
•	To encourage local communities to support the Armed Forces community in their areas 
•	To nurture public understanding and awareness amongst the public of issues affecting the Armed Forces community
•	To recognise and remember the sacrifices faced by the Armed Forces Community 
•	To encourage activities which help to integrate the Armed Forces Community into local life 
•	To encourage the Armed Forces Community to help and support the wider community, whether through participation in events and joint projects, or other forms of engagement
description:
Armed Forces Covenant - Tameside 
Overall Strategy from the Covenant Partnership
1 The work around the Covenant is not only for armed Forces Day and Remembrance Day but to engage the community to increase awareness in the community on a long term and daily basis.
2 It should be part of a plan which evolves over time and which builds on experience and ideas through the year and year on year.
3 That as many people as possible should be reached with at least a raising of awareness, progressing to participation and clear community and services benefits.
4 That as many partners organisations should be brought into the plan and encouraged to contribute and suggest activities and projects.
5 Innovation from all sectors and participants should be encouraged and developed to fit the wider aims.  
In doing this we should have a template that we can use to examine projects and ideas and see how they best fit with those aims of the covenant.
These may be;
Communication
•	A comprehensive and effective marketing and communications strategy.
•	Build on branding and awareness of the Covenant in the Borough.
•	Ensure that each of the aims of the Covenant are addressed through activity and awareness raising.
•	Develop the marketing and advocacy offer to reach out to more people, both ex-service and civilians.
•	Seek to develop the public understanding and awareness of the Covenant in Tameside and the breath of the work, - this is a key undertaking from the 2015 Armed Forces Covenant Report.

Engagement and Participation
•	To build on the work of our first two Covenant bids within the covenant for communities agenda.
•	To further encourage initiatives which meet the aims of the Covenant in communities in terms of integration and participation. 
•	To encourage the wider community to take an interest and get involved in projects and initiatives in the Borough through active participation.
Partners
•	Partners may well cross Local Authority and even regional boundaries and added value can best be achieved through effective partner working.
•	To develop partnerships on all levels as the next developmental stage of the Covenant in Tameside – see separate plan for this work.
The Covenant Plan for Tameside provides an exciting and diverse plan for the development of the Covenant in Tameside, through strategic development and partnership working.  
The two tier approach of Strategic Partnership and Working Group (TASC) is to ensure a programme to engage as many as possible whilst putting into place a Covenant model and framework with time limited paid leadership.
This model aims to create further capacity and a range of direct knowledge through a diverse volunteer group, incorporating a wide range of expertise and representation, which will inform and practically deliver on strategic outcomes agreed by the Strategic Partnership for Armed Forces in Tameside.

name: Sanctuary
shortDescription: A hot meal and music on alternate Wednesday evenings at Mustard Tree on Ancoats. NB Not on every week!
description: Every other Wednesday we provide a hot meal and entertainment at Ancoats. Dates/details tbc

name: Change4Good
shortDescription: Change4Good is an outreach service which aims to be the link between the person on the street and the support, information and advice they need.
description:
Change4Good is a volunteer led outreach project which aims to give help, information and advice to people rough sleeping, begging or homeless. 

We want REAL change not SPARE change. 

We build up relationships with people so that we can understand the issues they are facing and what they want help with. We an then begin to sign post them towards the most appropriate support to help make long term, sustainable changes. 

We work with some of the most vulnerable people in our community; socially isolated, substance users, people who have mental or physical health problems.

Change4Good is the link between the person on the street and the support organisation. 

We are a project ran by the award winning outreach charity Mancunian Way (www.mancunianway.org.uk)
donationDescription:
Change4Good is passionate about accommodation and health. We only work with rough sleepers, people who beg and those who are homeless in some way. We only work on the streets of Manchester: you'll normally find one of our workers or volunteers sat down next to someone on the street of Manchester. 

Since The Mancunian Way started funding our project and we recruited a part time street support worker we've had some successful getting people off the streets and into accommodation (15 since July 2016) and helped many people access health care they need. 

We've spent over £500 of Big Change money on practical bits and pieces people around the street need - like transport to accommodation, phones to reconnect with support services and family or waterproof boots to prevent trench food. 

We want to do more of this but need your help! 

About £10 pays for one hour of outreach by someone who has knowledge, information, advice, connections into support and the ability to get people into accommodation and help with health needs. 

A coffee or a meal deal only helps for such a short period. A support worker working on the streets of Manchester can make a real difference to people who have to call our streets "home". 

Change4Good - Real change, not spare change.

name: Coffee4Craig
shortDescription: Holistic homelessness support
description: Coffee4Craig is a charity that run street kitchens, an evening drop in service, and also work one to one with people on the streets, signposting to relevant services and offering advice. They also work alongside local councils to change the way services work together.
donationDescription: We rely on public donations to continue the work we do improving the lives of the homeless community and supporting people into accommodation.
itemsDonationDescription: Food, clothes and other items needed. Please drop off donations to Project 34, 32-34 Weaste Rd, Salford. M5 5FW.

name: Mustard Tree
shortDescription: We believe in a Greater Manchester where everyone has the opportunity to be a connected, valued, and contributing member of society.
description:
Since 1994, Mustard Tree has transformed the lives of people in Greater Manchester who are trapped in poverty or homelessness, by enabling them to gain the skills and self-confidence they need to reach their full potential. 

Our focus is on tackling both the causes and consequences of poverty by offering:

Provision: When people are in crisis we offer food, clothing and furniture. By meeting their basic needs we establish a relationship of trust, and open the door of welcome, hope and possibility. 

Progression: We offer life-skills, training, volunteering, education, mentoring and employment opportunities to help people to increase their resilience, and enable them to escape poverty and homelessness – for good. 

Partnership: We work collaboratively with our beneficiaries, enabling them to contribute to the Mustard Tree Community, and work with them to set self-determined goals, as well as working with individuals, agencies, businesses and community groups to broker long-term solutions to the poverty and inequality in our city.
donationDescription: Mustard tree rely on donations to help fight poverty and support local people in Greater Manchester.
itemsDonationDescription: Please refer to the Mustard Tree site for the most up to date information on the specific items needed and drop-off/pick-up arrangements

name: Emmaus Bolton
shortDescription: Emmaus offers you a home, work in a social enterprise and an opportunity for you to gain confidence, training and any support you may need to live independently again. To join an Emmaus community you have to commit to working full-time in the social enterprise but the rewards for doing so are great. Help is available in things you wish to change in your life. This can cover anything – personal development, training, career development, and support to live independently. The community is a drug and alcohol free environment and we have access to alcohol and drugs support.

name: Christchurch Church Hall
shortDescription: Drop-in centre for homeless people. They offer soup, sandwiches, support and advice. They have a Food Store
description:
Drop-in centre for homeless people every Monday (apart from Bank Holidays) 1.00pm -  2.30pm.
They offer soup and sandwiches as well as support and advice. They have a Food Store on Wednesdays from 10.00am - 12.00pm

addresses.street1: (corner of Block Lane and Oxford Street)

name: Barnabus
shortDescription: Christian homeless charity.
description:
Barnabus is a Christian Homeless Charity based in Manchester. We started over 24 years ago with just one man walking the streets, giving out food and drink to the homeless.

We now offer a lifeline to 600 visiting homeless and vulnerable people each week, many of whom have severe addictions or mental health issues. We support their physical, emotional and spiritual needs and do all we can to help them get back into mainstream society. We have received the 'unsung heroes' Queens award for Voluntary Service, but we do not receive any government funding, we rely entirely on donations.
donationDescription:
To enable us to continue our lifesaving work on the streets of Manchester we need your support, there are many different ways that you can help us to meet the needs of the homeless and vulnerable.

This year has been exceptionally challenging due to the impact of the economic climate, we have seen an increase in the number of people seeking help +40% yet unfortunately we have also seen giving decrease by 28%. We hope you will feel moved to help us in our work.

Link to our website
Include a link to our website from yours with a direct link to donate to our brick appeal we can supply you with our logo, link to our online giving facility and website email carol@barnabusmanchester.co.uk for full information.
itemsDonationDescription: We can receive your donations at our Barnabus Support Office: 61 Bloom Street, Manchester M1 3LY, Monday - Friday, 10am - 3pm. If you have a large number of items (more than a car) or you are unable to drop offitems during these times, please email Yvonne admin@barnabusmanchester.co.uk or Tel: 0161 237 3223

name: Boaz Trust
shortDescription: Ending asylum destitution in the UK
description: The Boaz Trust is a Christian charity serving destitute asylum seekers and refugees in Greater Manchester. Our aim is to end asylum destitution. We want to see people who are seeking sanctuary in the UK leading fulfilling lives. To this end we provide accommodation and support for destitute asylum seekers and refugees, and speak up with asylum seekers in campaigning for a more compassionate asylum system.
donationDescription:
Boaz housing and support would not be possible without your support. If you are able, please consider supporting Boaz’s work with destitute asylum seekers and refugees in Greater Manchester.

Financial support

£30 could pay for a legal appointment enabling clients to submit fresh evidence
£20 could pay for bedding and emergency food and toiletries for a homeless asylum seeker
£10 could pay for a food parcel for an asylum seeker for one week
£5 could pay for a bus pass allowing an asylum seeker the freedom to travel and participate in Boaz Life activities.
itemsDonationDescription:
Items can be delivered to The Boaz Trust at the address below for the attention of Lisa Lee. Her contact details are 0161 202 1056, info@boaztrust.org.uk.

The Boaz Trust
First Floor
110 Oldham Road
Manchester
M4 6AG

name: Adullam Homes Housing Association Limited
shortDescription: Adullam Homes Housing Association Limited is a specialist provider of housing and support services.
description: The housing association houses and supports 1,000 people at any one time throughout England.

name: Chapter 1 - The Limes
shortDescription: Hostel for young men.
description: The Limes provides supported housing for young men, also education and training to homeless and marginalised people as well as the local community on a weekly basis.
donationDescription: As a charity, Chapter 1 relies on the kindness of our supporters to fund much of our vital work. And the more generous our supporters are, the more vulnerable people we can reach providing housing, support and services for people who might otherwise have nowhere to turn.
itemsDonationDescription:
Chapter 1 is open 24/7 and any member of staff on site will be able to take delivery of items. Pauline Gaye is the service manager and she can be contacted on the following:

P:0161 224 5883 
F:0161 224 5893
Mobile:07970 303333
Iphone:07841604076
paulineg@chapter1.co.uk

The Limes 
76 Daisy Bank Rd 
Victoria Park 
Longsight Manchester M14 5GL

name: Women's direct access hostel
shortDescription: Women's hostel and advice centre.
description:
This service offers 24 hour accommodation and telephone advice; single rooms in good quality hostel accommodation; moving on options including permanent rehousing in Manchester or elsewhere in the country; help with benefits agency grants and loans, and other aspects of moving house.

If you are a woman in need of refuge you can come to the centre at any time of the day or night. The following day we will do our best to find you suitable accommodation and support.

PLEASE NOTE We are currently at a temporary location while the service is redesigned.
itemsDonationDescription: Items needed most are Shampoo, Soap, Shower Gel, Bath Towels, Toothbrushes, Toothpaste, Body Cream, Hand Cream, Sanitary Towels, Hair Brushes, Hats, New Kickers (all sizes), Hoodies, Track Suits, Socks, Gloves, House Slippers, Chocolate, Cuppa Soups, Pot Noodles, Juice, Fizzy Drinks, Cups/Mugs, Bowls, Plates, Spoons, Forks, Books, DVDs, TV Aerials

name: Cornerstone
shortDescription: Adult day centre with a range of services
description: Cornerstone is a day centre providing services to adults facing a wide range of social issues including homelessness, poverty, social isolation, poor mental health, drug and alcohol addiction. We operate an open door policy and welcome people from all backgrounds with our aim being to offer support to our clients, improve their prospects and enhance their quality of life.
donationDescription: Cornerstone receives no public funds and is entirely dependent on grants from charitable trusts and individual benefactors. Cornerstone is very grateful to all those who have supported our cause since 1991.

name: Emmaus Salford
shortDescription: Emmaus Salford is a charity that supports homeless people by providing them with a home and meaningful work in a community setting.
description: Emmaus Salford is not emergency accommodation or a hostel, we are a residential community where people come to make it their home. People who join the community (known as companions) have to commit to working to the best of their ability in the Emmaus Salford social enterprises. This work helps to fund the accommodation, living costs and ongoing support. Work is an important part of the Emmaus ethos as it gives people a focus each day, an opportunity for personal development and allows companions to grow the community so that it can give opportunities to others.
donationDescription:
Your donation will help us to provide a home and meaningful work to people experiencing homelessness and social exclusion.

All our companions want is an opportunity to work their way out of homelessness and, with your support, we can offer them that.

Making a donation couldn’t be easier. You can make a one-off donation to Emmaus Salford or set up a monthly donation.
itemsDonationDescription:
We rely on continued support and kind donations to keep us going and always do our utmost to sell, recycle or otherwise get an income from every item donated to us. 

We are happy to accept most household items but there are some exceptions for either legal or practical reasons. This includes soft furnishings without a fire label, safety items, baby equipment or any item that is not in good, saleable condition.

name: Homes of Hope
shortDescription: Homes and support for people experiencing homelessness
description: Homes of Hope is a supported housing project for men aged 25+ who either have been, or are at risk of, sleeping rough and homelessness. We provide support for men in a fully furnished shared 3 or 4 bedroom house for up to two years.
donationDescription:
We are a non-profit organisation and so our focus is entirely on making a difference in the lives of real people.

Every donation to Homes of Hope contributes to the day-to-day running of our current houses or to the setting up of new homes. So whether it’s an annual gas safety check, bedding and furniture and ongoing maintenance or a new house, your money makes a huge difference. We invite you to become a homes of hope supporter. Your giving makes a real difference, thank you!
itemsDonationDescription: Bedding and cleaning materials are the items most in demand.

name: Mad Dogs Street Project
shortDescription: Food and personal items direct to rough sleepers.
description: We take hot food, water, clothing, sleeping bags & toiletries out to rough sleepers 5 nights a week Sun-Thurs
itemsDonationDescription:
Food and Drink
We always need food, both fresh and canned. We especially need non-perishable items and bulk carb items like rice, pasta, tomatoes, beans and any ingredients which can be made into stews. We also need a steady supply of small bottles of water.
All our meals are divided up into individual portions and it’s important to keep the meals hot for as long as possible, so we are very grateful for regular donations of foil food containers, such as the ones used for take-away dishes. Similarly, we need plastic spoons to give out with each meal.
Clothing and Survival Supplies
All clothing is welcome, but we have a particular need for socks, underwear , waterproofs and tracky bottoms. Seasonal items items such as hats, coats, gloves in the winter and t-shirts & lighter warm clothes in the summer. You don’t have to buy new though; second-hand clothing and supplies are extremely welcome, but we do stress that they must be clean and wearable.

name: Manchester Central Foodbank
shortDescription: Helping local people in crisis.
description: We provide three days’ nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis.
donationDescription:
Big or small, every gift you give helps transform lives.
Our foodbank is run by local people for local people – we rely on the community’s support to ensure we can continue to stop people going hungry. Can you invest in the future of our project and help us provide much-needed support to people in crisis in our community?
itemsDonationDescription:
Our foodbank relies on your goodwill and support.
Over 90% of the food distributed by foodbanks in The Trussell Trust network is donated by the public – that’s why your food donations are absolutely vital to our ability to give everyone referred to us a balanced and nutritious three day supply of food.
Please check the site for the latest shopping list and details of food donation points.

name: Emmaus Mossley
shortDescription: Emmaus Mossley is a charity that supports 26 formerly homeless people by providing them with a home and work in a community setting.
description:
Emmaus Mossley gives people a home, meaningful work in a social enterprise and an opportunity to get themselves back on their feet again.

Emmaus provides a home for as long as someone needs it... it’s not a bed for the night. We give people stability and the opportunity to properly deal with the reasons why they become homeless.

We are unique in that our companions (the people we support) work in every area of our social enterprise. Without their skills, experience, hard work and dedication our charity would not function. We have our own Secondhand Superstore and workshops where donated goods are repaired, refurbished and sold on to generate an income to help sustain our work. Companions are offered the opportunity for personal development, training and support to live independently. 

Emmaus Mossley is an independent charity but we are part of a wider federation of over 25 Emmaus communities in the UK and connected to a much larger international Emmaus movement. We are non-religious and open to people of all backgrounds and beliefs.
donationDescription: Make a donation to support Emmaus Mossley and help us to provide a home and meaningful work to people experiencing homelessness and social exclusion.
itemsDonationDescription: One very important way in which you can help Emmaus Mossley is to donate items which we can then sell. We rely on continued support and kind donations to keep us going and always do our utmost to sell, recycle or otherwise get an income from everything you give us.

name: H3
shortDescription: Helping the Homeless into Housing
description: H3 is a registered charity that supports homeless people, and those at risk of homelessness, through a range of inclusive support activities across Stockport.
itemsDonationDescription:
Men's and women's toiletries, bedding, baby food and clothes, cleaning and kitchenware are the items that are needed most, but all other items highlighted are gratefully accepted.

They do have a van so a pick up could be arranged, but they are fairly short on drivers so a drop off is preferred. Drop offs can be made any time from 9am - 8pm at Brindale House, Brindale Rd, Brinnington, Stockport SK5 8DL and just need to be left under 'H3 Donations.' 

If items need to be picked up then please contact Molly Bishop on admin@h-3.org.uk to arrange.

name: Myriad Foundation
shortDescription: Support for people in need in our local area.
description:
The Myriad Foundation is a UK-based Islamic organisation established in September 2013, to convey the message of Islam locally and nationally through our actions. 
We have a variety of projects including a FoodBank based in Levenshulme and a twice weekly soup kitchen (Soup N Smiles) in Manchester City Centre.
donationDescription: As a 100% volunteer organisation, all donations go directly to those that we work so hard to help. We require donations to continue the work we do in the best way possible.
itemsDonationDescription: Currently hats and coats would be most welcome.

name: Emmelines Pantry Parlour
shortDescription: Food bank for women.
description: We are a Food Bank for women in need, based in Manchester. We offer support to women and their families by referral via admin@thepankhurstcentre.org.uk
itemsDonationDescription: Items can be collected and Karen Wilson should be contacted to arrange this. Her contact details are wilsonkaren431@gmail.com or 0161 273 5673 and is available Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

name: Narrowgate
shortDescription: Emergency Accommodation
description: We provide emergency accommodation for homeless men and women.  When there are vacancies referrals can be made via our website form on Mon, Tues and Fri from 9am-11am.  We provide safe accommodation and food for up to three months, registered referral agencies are expected to work with clients to find a pathway to more suitable accommodation. We do not operate any automatic exclusions.
donationDescription:
There are many practical ways you can contribute to Manchester City Mission, including prayer, volunteering, and  giving financially.
We need finances to, among other things, provide food for our guests, pay utility bills, and to pay our staff.
itemsDonationDescription: Items must be new or in excellent condition and can be dropped anytime at the Narrowgate Emergency Night Accommodation, Manchester City Mission, Churchill Way, Salford, M6 5BU.

name: Manchester Life Centre
shortDescription: Food bank and job club
description: The Feed the 5000 project is a food distribution centre providing a service for the geographical areas of northeast Manchester and Greater Manchester. They also have a Christians Against Poverty (CAP) job club on Mondays as part of their outreach programme.
donationDescription: We value one-off and continuing gifts for the hugely import role they play in the development of Manchester Life Centre.
itemsDonationDescription:
Manchester Life Centre mostly require food, drink and toiletries. Clothing is an additional need that we have seen grow over time, however they aren't necessarily required every week by their service users. The demand for items for children and babies is not as high as it is for adults, so they may not always be needed. 

They are based at Faithlife Centre, 5 Mary Street, Manchester, M3 1NH and are open every Thursday between 4 - 6pm so items can be dropped off then.
If a collection is required then please contact Miriam on miriam@manchesterlifecentre.co.uk.

name: Fallowfield and Withington Foodbank
shortDescription: Foodbank under the Trussell Trust serving communities
description: The Foodbank Network was founded in 2004 after four years of developing the original foodbank based in Salisbury. Since then The Trussell Trust has helped communities work together to launch foodbanks nationwide in a wide range of towns and cities. In 2016/17, The Trussell Trust’s Foodbank Network provided 1,182,954 three-day emergency food supplies and support to UK people in crisis. Of these, over 430,000 went to children.
donationDescription:
Big or small, every gift you give helps transform lives.

Our foodbank is run by local people for local people – we rely on the community’s support to ensure we can continue to stop people going hungry. Can you invest in the future of our project and help us provide much-needed support to people in crisis in our community?
itemsDonationDescription:
Our foodbank relies on your goodwill and support.

Over 90% of the food distributed by foodbanks in The Trussell Trust network is donated by the public – that’s why your food donations are absolutely vital to our ability to give everyone referred to us a balanced and nutritious three day supply of food.

name: Greater Together Manchester
shortDescription: Greater Together Manchester coordinates the Greater Manchester Winter Night Shelter.
description: The Greater Manchester Winter Night Shelter is a rolling night shelter, using 7 different venues per week. We offer shelter and hospitality to 12 male rough sleepers each night. Referrals are currently via the Booth Centre. These are due to open on 1st November.
donationDescription: Greater Together Manchester runs the Greater Manchester Winter Night Shelters in Manchester and Salford. We rely on charitable giving to ensure we can give shelter and safety to rough sleepers throughout the winter months.
itemsDonationDescription:
Items that are most needed are underwear, shoes, and good rucksacks or suitcases that the men can use to carry their stuff around in.

The central drop off point is Church of the Apostles, Ridgeway Street, Miles Platting M40 7FY and the priest in charge is Revd Ellie Trimble. The church is closed on a Monday, but most other days it is open and people can always call and ask what time is best to drop of donations. Revd Ellies number is 07887601451

name: Depaul UK - Manchester
shortDescription: Depaul UK helps homeless and disadvantaged young people fulfil their potential in the community
description:
The Depaul Group began in 1989 in response to the growing number of homeless people on the streets of London. 

Depaul quickly grew into a national charity in the UK and, from 2002, expanded internationally, starting in Ireland.

name: Salford Loaves and Fishes
shortDescription: Drop-in centre for homeless people.
description:
Salford Loaves & Fishes a Drop-In Centre; a safe place for homeless and vulnerable people in Salford.  
NOTE: This service will move to Mona St from Monday, 24th October 2016.
donationDescription:
The centre relies on grants and the generosity of Churches and individuals for its funding. We are grateful for all monetary ‘one off’ donations. We can easily process one off or regular donations online via Virgin Money Giving. You can even set up your own fundraising page to raise money on our behalf. Please speak to a member of staff for more details on 0161 737 8775.
Alternatively, you can download a Standing Order form from the site. 

Did you know? You can raise funds for Salford Loaves and Fishes whilst you shop online. 
Please visit www.easyfundraising.org.uk to register. It’s FREE and easy to join! Once registered you can shop with your favourite retailers - there are hundreds to choose from. The retailer will then donate a percentage of the purchase to Salford Loaves and Fishes.
itemsDonationDescription:
We greatly appreciate donations of non-perishable food and are happy to advise on the most suitable food. Our users greatly value the use of bathing facilities and so toiletries are always in demand. Clothing for both men and women are always very appreciated, again, we can advise on the most suitable items. We are currently in need of the following items:

Jars of sauces, tinned meats,
Sugar, coffee, tinned vegetables,
Flavoured noodles, tinned fish, tinned fruit, baked beans, tins of tomatoes and any other non-perishable goods.

Other items that would be useful are: 
Socks, boxer shorts, underpants, disposable razors, shaving gel, shaving foam, shampoo and shower gel.

To arrange delivery please contact Nicola Daly on 0161 737 8775.

name: Self Help
shortDescription: Improving mental health
description: A user led mental health charity based in the North West. We provide support , advice and techniques you need to help take control of your life.
donationDescription:
Getting together with friends, family and neighbours or taking on a personal challenge is a great way to support Self Help plus we think it feels great too.

The only limit on what you do is your imagination. You could take part in an organised event such as a run, skydive, cycle or swim. Or why not organise your own event; from holding a concert, to washing cars, to collections and sponsored silences – the options are limitless.

Every penny our raised will support our services and improve mental health. We will concentrate on those services that do not get further funding to help us reach more people who need support – such as The Sanctuary, which provides support to adults who are experiencing panic attacks, anxiety, depression, suicidal thoughts or are in crisis.

name: Stockport Loaves and Fishes
shortDescription: Christian run community drop in
description: We run a soup kitchen every Sunday evening from 6 to 7.30pm at Stockport Baptist Church nr Greek Street, where we provide a hot meal and drinks, a warm and friendly environment where you can get tents, sleeping bags, clothing and toiletries, advice and guidance.  You also get a carry out bag of food after you have been fed.
donationDescription: Big or small, every gift you give helps transform the lives of homeless and disadvantaged people. We couldn’t do what we do without your support. We are completely reliant upon charitable donations and could not continue without the support we receive from the general public as well as churches, schools and other local organisations. If you would like to set up a regular donation to Loaves and Fishes then please download the standing order form on our site. If you would like to make a one off donation then please select the donate button on the site.
itemsDonationDescription: We are always in need of donations of clothes (must be clean and in good condition), shoes, boots, trainers, warm socks, underwear, toiletries, sleeping bags, tents, pillows, blankets, warm coats, hats, scarves, gloves, rucksacks. Plus food donations, particularly of tinned meats, tinned fish, tinned fruit, long life milk, tea and coffee, biscuits, cakes, chocolates, snacks.

name: The Housing Link
shortDescription: Supported Accommodation provider in Bury Greater Manchester
description: Provide supported accommodation and associated services for single homeless people aged 16 upwards in Bury, Greater Manchester.  Support is provided in arrange of settings from 24 hour hostel to single person flats.  Support is time limited to two years and can only be accessed on completion of a referral via the Bury MBC Central Access Point
donationDescription:
Because our clients will find it harder to stay warm over the winter.  please help Jack so that he can stay warm.

Jack and his friends will be feeling the cold this winter, please help them by donating so that we can continue to help them during the cold winter months.  The temperature is falling and storms are on the way, please support Jack and his friends through the work we do to keep them warm.

Thank you for taking the time to read these pages.

name: Manchester Integrated Drug and Alcohol Service
shortDescription: Assessment, information and advice, treatment and referral for users of drugs or alcohol.
description:
We are a recovery-oriented service, and try to inspire service users to work towards abstinence as a goal. We believe in service user choice and will support service users on longer term treatment journeys if that’s what they choose. We take referrals from any source as long as they’re with the person’s consent. Clients can also self refer to the service. 

Depending on location in Manchester please use one of the following numbers to make a referral:
0161226552 (Central - Zion Centre); 
01612140770 (North - Carnarvon St);  
01619458772 (South - Bradnor Rd).

name: Walking With The Wounded
shortDescription: Walking With The Wounded, supporting our Veterans into settled accommodation, sustainable employment and regain their independence.
description: Our Mission: Support all veterans with physical, mental or social injury to gain the skills and qualifications necessary to develop new careers outside the military, re-integrate into society and provide long-term security for themselves and their families.
donationDescription:
Raising funds to retrain and re-skill our wounded and support them in finding new careers outside the Military. You can help by making a donation or fundraising for the charity.

Please click the link to see how you can donate to Walking With The Wounded
itemsDonationDescription: We have 10 homeless veterans in two locations, most have come from homeless situations, so any toiletries, TV’s, and outdoor clothing, including tents, and sleeping bags, would be of great benefit.

name: The Wellspring
shortDescription: Resource centre for homeless and disadvantaged people
description: The Wellspring provides numerous services and everything is completely free of charge. The project is open 365 days a year.
donationDescription: The Wellspring supports homeless people with a range of services including housing, health, education, jobs, CV's, advice, alcohol & drug support, mental health support, training courses, 1-1 support, referrals to other services, signposting, employment support, benefits support.
itemsDonationDescription:
Wellspring is always in need of the following donations. Donations of these items can be dropped off at The Wellspring, Harvey St, Stockport, SK11YD Any day of the year. The Project is open Monday to Thursday 9am-8pm and Friday to Sunday 9am – 3pm.

Clothing
Any kind of clothing is most welcome. Warm clothing for giving to people who are rough sleeping or homeless is especially good. Any clothing that gets donated to The Wellspring that we can not use is then sold on to raise funds for the Charity.

Food
In date tinned and packages food is always needed. The Wellspring runs a food service and serves around 100-150 meals per day to homeless and disadvantaged people. Fresh food and baked goods are also very welcome and much needed.

Toiletries
Toiletries packs are given out regularly. roll on deodorants are especially welcome. The Wellspring does not give out aerosol sprays of any kind.

The Ruck Sack Project
The Wellspring runs and takes part in The Rucksack Project for Stockport. Donations of items for The Rucksack project can be made at anytime. Wellspring staff and volunteers provide regular street outreach giving donated Rucksack Project Items out directly to people on the streets. The Wellspring also operates a clothing and item store that homeless people can access daily.

name: Centrepoint North
shortDescription: Giving homeless young people a future
description: Centrepoint North provides a wide range of services to support young people towards an independent life as an adult. Our services range from practical support and advice for those at immediate risk of homelessness, to help with learning how to find employment, cook healthy meals or budget for household bills. Our aim is to help young people to find and maintain a home life that’s safe and secure, with the means to support themselves, live healthily and be free from harm.
donationDescription:
Centrepoint North (formerly the Young People Support Foundation (YPSF)) provides a wide range of services to support young people towards an independent life as an adult.

Our services range from practical support and advice for those at immediate risk of homelessness, to help with learning how to find employment, cook healthy meals or budget for household bills.

Our aim is to help young people to find and maintain a home life that’s safe and secure, with the means to support themselves, live healthily and be free from harm.

We work with young people aged 16-25, although some of our services are available for those aged 14 and 15. (If you’re 14 or 15 and need help, contact us to find out if our services are suitable for you.) It doesn't matter if you’re living with parents or relatives, in council care, sleeping rough, are single or part of a couple or have children. If we can’t provide the help you need, we’ll be able to give you the details of someone who can and may be able to set up an appointment for you. Any young person can ask us for help no matter what their background, race, religion, sexual orientation, history or health status. All our services are free and confidential.
itemsDonationDescription:
Centrepoint North don’t currently have the storage space for the bigger items, however men’s and women’s toiletries are always welcome.
These can be delivered to the following address, but please call ahead on 0161 228 7654 to ensure someone will be available.
City Centre Project
52 Oldham Street
Manchester
M4 1LE

name: Big Issue North
shortDescription: Big Issue North publishes a weekly magazine which provides people with few other means the opportunity to earn an income.
description: Big Issue North is a business solution to a social problem. It is a limited company employing staff to produce and distribute a weekly magazine that is sold by homeless people and others who have no means of earning an income. Sold in the North West and Yorkshire and Humber, Vendors buy the magazine for £1.25 and sell it for £2.50 keeping the profit they make.
donationDescription: We rely on donations to be able to support vendor of Big Issue North to reach their goals and currently receive no grant funding so please support us today.

name: On the Out
shortDescription: We are staffed by men and women who have experienced life in prison. We offer welcoming peer support, plus practical help and advice.
description: Within our group, people who have a shared experience of prison - and life on release - support and guide each other. We offer support and guidance around benefits, addiction, housing, getting ID, debt and money, family and legal issues, employment, well-being and adjusting to being out of prison. We also offer routes to develop mentoring skills, including ongoing training and accredited qualifications. We are strongly supported by key agencies within the community, who work with us to form a holistic package of support for individuals as they leave prison/within the community.
donationDescription:
We are trying to raise money to help with the day to day running costs of our project - postage, printer ink, travel expenses for workers who are both office based and working out on the street. We are also hoping to raise money to help fund primary ID for people leaving prison, as this is an identified barrier to housing/employment. Any donations at all would be very much appreciated. 
Thank you

name: SPIN
shortDescription: Street kitchen and clothing.
description:
SPIN (Supporting People In Need) operate a street kitchen in Manchester feeding and clothing the homeless every Thursday evening.

We are self financing and are always needing warm clothing, donations of food.

name: Salford Foodbank
shortDescription: Foodbank under the Trussell Trust serving communities in Salford
description: The Foodbank Network was founded in 2004 after four years of developing the original foodbank based in Salisbury. Since then The Trussell Trust has helped communities work together to launch foodbanks nationwide in a wide range of towns and cities. In 2016/17, The Trussell Trust’s Foodbank Network provided 1,182,954 three-day emergency food supplies and support to UK people in crisis. Of these, over 430,000 went to children.

name: Helping Hearts Homeless Foundation
shortDescription: Started in 2013 with 2 women and a flask we now have volunteers to help us take out sleeping bags hot food clothing toiletries etc to the streets.
description:
We are a volunteers run group based in stockport, covering Greater Manchester supporting homeless people before, during and after rough sleeping. We help with all basic needs food, clothing etc. We befriend people and earn their trust which then allows people to open up about any further needs they may have including rough sleeping, addiction, mental health, prostitution.

We visit people when they are in hospital or prison taking up essentials.

We are currently in the process of looking into opening a resource centre which will include, kitchen, showers, launderette and overnight shelter.

name: Re>Build
shortDescription: REBUILD runs projects for vulnerable people, including a furniture reuse project and helping people from a huge range of backgrounds back to work.
description: Affordable furniture and skills to people living in disadvantaged situations. In the last 10 years we have helped over 13,000 households with furniture, 400 volunteers and have had 900 people attend 90 courses. We support low self-esteem sufferers, unemployed, mental health sufferers, lone parents, domestic abuse survivors, refugees, people with disabilities, young people and ex-service personnel. We support these people by providing furniture to those on low incomes and offer volunteering for people to learn new skills and return to work. We also run courses for disadvantaged people to build skills.
donationDescription:
You can give a on-off or regular donation of cash through the Local Giving website where for every £5 donated we could receive a further £5.  Or you can donate through the Big Give via our website at: http://www.rebuildbury.org.uk/ 
With just £5 we can fund a day’s travel enabling a volunteer to be part of our team, learn new skills, obtain references for work and reduce isolation and anxiety.
itemsDonationDescription:
Here at RE>BUILD we reuse a large range of household items from sofas to the kitchen sink, literally. A more detailed list can be seen below. RE>BUILD would not be possible without your very generous donations. There are multiple ways in which you can donate household items and if you are unsure if we can reuse something then just ask us:

You can call us on 0161-764-0444 to arrange a collection date.
Drop the items off at our warehouse (4 Park Road, Bury, BL9 5BQ)
Drop them off at our container at the Radcliffe recycling centre at Cemetery Rd.
What we reuse:
Living room
Sofas/suites, Pouffes, TV stands, Coffee tables, Rugs, TV’s, DVD/video players, Consoles, Freeview boxes, Vacuums, Hi-fi systems, Lamps
Dining room
Dining tables, Dining chairs, Sideboards, Wall units, Display cabinets
Kitchen
Small electrical appliances (kettles, irons, coffee makers and more), Microwaves,
Electrical cookers, Dishwasher, Fridges and freezers, Washing machines, Dryers,
Kitchen utensils, Cutlery, Pots and Pans
Bedroom
Beds (all sizes), Bunk beds/cabin beds, Mattresses, Headboards, Cots, Changing tables,
Bedside tables, Wardrobes, Chest of drawers, Tall boys, Dressing tables, Mirrors
Small items
Pictures, Ornaments, Bedding (sheets, duvets, pillows)
Others
Bikes.

name: Justlife
shortDescription: Services for people close to street homelessness.
description: The Justlife Centre provides services for those that are 'close to the street'. Our friendly morning drop in and weekly meals act as a means of encouraging greater engagement in our workshop programme and project work, which in turn help to build relationships, self-confidence, skills and experience. This ultimately will enable people to make a positive contribution to society through volunteering, employment or enterprise creation.
donationDescription: Justlife aims to raise the aspirations of vulnerable people by opening doorways to healthcare, treatment, housing and employment.

name: Tameside Housing Advice
shortDescription: Tameside Housing Advice can provide you with help and advice on all aspects of housing, and help resolve your housing problems
description:
If you’re in housing difficulty or worried about your housing situation, the most important thing is to get advice as soon as possible. If you think you are, or about to become homeless, contact us on 0161 331 2700.
If you are in financial difficulties and having problems paying your rent or your mortgage payments a referral can be made to the council’s Debt Advice team who are co-located at the Housing Advice office.
Outside of these hours, if you have a homeless emergency and you are homeless tonight contact: 0161 331 2888.

name: Greater Manchester Law Centre
shortDescription: We provide free, face-to-face, professional legal advice and representation. We are also a campaigning organisation for free access to justice.
description:
In the face of cuts to legal aid and advice services, the Greater Manchester Law Centre defiantly opened its doors in September 2016.

Our main legal services at the moment are in Employment Support Allowance claims and Personal Independence Payments, community care and prison law.

We are providing face- to-face, high quality legal advice and professional legal representation, covering welfare, disability, benefits, employment, prison law, and community care. Our experienced and professional advisers support service users from when they walk through the door with a confusing form, to when they need representation in tribunals.

As well as expanding our much-needed services, we are  ghting together for free access to justice, to give our community a voice, and to support the next generation of social welfare lawyers.
donationDescription: Your contributions are vital in securing key, free advice and representation services for those in need.
itemsDonationDescription:
We are always looking for volunteers to help at our premises with the services we offer to the public: advice work, reception and signposting or general admin work.

We also have a second volunteer stream to help with our campaigns, community outreach, fundraising, social media presence etc.

Please don’t hesitate to get in touch with us if you have any other skills to offer. We are running an office and sometimes need a handywoman/man. Or you can help with transport to events, bake a cake… anything, please get in touch with development@gmlaw.org.uk.

name: Asylum Support Housing Advice (GMIAU)
shortDescription: ASHA's central aims are to provide support, advocacy and advice for asylum seekers who are at risk of homelessness and destitution.
description:
We hold 2 drop in sessions per week on Wednesday and Thursday mornings seeing the first 15 people. The service is targeted at people seeking asylum who are at risk of homelessness or are having difficulties with the accommodation and support provided by the Home Office. 
We have links to several other asylum and refugee charities and destitution projects within Manchester and welcome referrals to assist people with applications for asylum support, dispersal requests and appeals against the termination or refusal of support. 
In addition to assisting with asylum support issues, we also help with access to healthcare, legal advice and education.

name: Greater Manchester Mental Health NHS
shortDescription: Greater Manchester Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust (GMMH) brings together the expertise of GMW and Manchester Mental Health and Social Care Trust
description:
The Trust provides inpatient and community-based mental health care for people living in Bolton, the city of Manchester, Salford and Trafford and a wide range of specialist mental health and substance misuse services across Greater Manchester, the north west of England and beyond.

The Trust employs around 4,750 members of staff, who deliver services from more than 130 locations. Over a 12-month period, we see in the region of 53,000 service users.

The business of GMMH is managed by a board of directors. The board work closely with the council of governors, who provide local accountability by representing the interests of members and partner organisations.

name: Manchester City Council
shortDescription: Manchester City Council is the local government authority for Manchester.
description:
If you have just become homeless, or might do in the next 28 days, the first thing to do is apply as homeless at your local council. The homelessness service is an emergency service, and you can also get advice or help to stay in your home.

If the council accepts you are homeless, they take on a duty of care which means they will try to house you immediately. You will then be "in the system”, and able to access other services for homeless people. You can visit the town hall, or call Manchester City Council's team on 0161 234 4692 Mon-Fri between 9am - 4.30pm, or out of hours in an emergency you can call 0161 234 5001.
