name: One Manchester
shortDescription: One Manchester is a unique social business that looks to innovative new approaches and partnerships to tackle the issues our neighbourhoods face.
description:
Together we manage a wide range of neighbourhoods, and over 12,500 homes, across south and east Manchester. That means not being just a landlord, but a connector and enabler of change, improvement and opportunity in our communities, bringing social value to all that we do. One Future is a free service to support residents of East and South Manchester into work through skills, experience and confidence boosting. We offer advice and a wide range of training, work placements, self-employment, apprenticeships and volunteering opportunities.
Work placements will give you an insight into the world of work, boost your confidence and offer on the job training that’s a great stepping stone into employment. 
Volunteering is a fantastic way to develop skills, build confidence and meet new people. We have a range of opportunities available in the Fallowfield library, IT classes for 50+, job club support and retirement housing scheme support.
Whatever you experience, background or ambitions, One Future can help you take the next step on the pathway to a more successful future!

name: Hope for Justice - Manchester
shortDescription: We exist to bring an end to modern slavery by rescuing victims, restoring lives and reforming society.
description:
Hope for Justice trains staff at facilities and organisations most likely to come into contact with victims of modern slavery and human trafficking to 'spot the signs' and to refer cases to us so we can assess them professionally and where necessary get victims out of situations of exploitation and work with police to bring their traffickers to justice.

As a vulnerable population, the homeless are frequently targeted by human traffickers for forced labour, sexual exploitation and other forms of modern slavery.

Hope for Justice is currently active in Manchester, West Yorkshire and the West Midlands, and also works in Northumberland, Scotland, Cambodia, Norway and the USA.
donationDescription:
FUND FREEDOM
Change Lives. End Slavery.
All money raised goes towards our vital work to bring an end to modern slavery by rescuing victims, restoring lives and reforming society.

name: Wood Street Mission
shortDescription:
Wood Street Mission is a registered children’s charity and 
 we help alleviate the effects of poverty on local children and their families.
description:
We run 5 different projects to help those in need:

 
   • Community Shop
   • Easter Project
   • SmartStart School Uniform Project
   • Children's Book Clubs
   • Christmas Project
Help is offered by a referral system whereby a family struggling to provide basic items for their children can access our service once they have been referred by a support worker. This is usually a Health Visitor, Housing Officer, Social Worker or similar. We work with all statutory services and voluntary agencies across Manchester and Salford to ensure as many families as possible in need of our support can be referred for help.
donationDescription:
Every donation you give helps us to make a real, positive difference to local children and families who are affected by poverty. 

  • £10 will provide a new toy and book for a child at Christmas.
 
  • £40 would kit out a child with new uniform for the start of the school year, helping them fit in and fulfil their potential
itemsDonationDescription: We need your donations of clean, good quality, new and used items to help us offer support to struggling local families through our community shop. All suitable donations go directly to families who need them.

name: Manchester Advocacy Hub
shortDescription: The Manchester Advocacy Hub was established in April 2015 and brings together all statutory advocacy provision in Manchester.
description:
What is Advocacy?

Advocacy is taking action to help people say what they want, secure their rights, represent their interests and obtain services they need. Advocates work in partnership with the people they support and take their side. Advocacy promotes social inclusion, equality and social justice.

name: BAND- Building A New Direction
shortDescription: BAND is a voluntary sector organisation operating mostly within the Borough of Bolton.
description:
We are proud to have been working alongside people with lived experience of a mental health condition for over 25 years.
We believe that everyone has the right and capability to lead an inclusive and meaningful life and our services are designed to support people to take steps towards achieving this.
The work we do is divided up into: Recovery; Volunteering; and Communities, Engagement & Representation.

description: Greater Manchester Police - Ashton

name: The Prince Trust
shortDescription: The Prince's Trust is a youth charity that helps change young lives.
description: Working with young people in Bury, Rochdale, Oldham, Bury and Wigan, we help 13 to 25-year-olds work towards their personal goals through Fairbridge, a free and fun personal development programme to equip you with the tools you need to move forward.

name: Stockport Without Abuse
shortDescription: Local charity who offer a range of services to help and support women, men and children who are affected by domestic abuse.
description:
Stockport Without Abuse has been around for over thirty years. In the sixties and seventies there was a huge drive by the women’s liberation movement to recognise and combat the issue of domestic violence and abuse, which was largely ignored by the police and courts, and accepted by society with the attitude ‘it’s only a domestic’.

Heaton Moor Women’s Group tried to find out what service provision was available in Stockport to help women and protect them from violence. This group formalised itself in 1975 to become Stockport Women’s Aid and opened the first refuge for women and children in Stockport.

Over the years, we have grown considerably and developed a whole range of services. Attitude to domestic abuse has changed considerably and we now work in close and strong partnership with our statutory, private and voluntary sector partners to keep victims safe and challenge public awareness of domestic abuse. 

In 2011, we changed our name to Stockport Without Abuse to reflect the support we offer to male victims and children as well as women.
donationDescription:
Stockport Without Abuse welcomes donations of any kind and without such generosity we would struggle to deliver the range of services currently available.

You can be assured that every penny raised goes directly to support the people who need us.

If you would like to make a donation, please telephone our Chief Executive on 0161 477 4271 or email info@stockportwithoutabuse.org.uk

Please be aware that if you are a current tax payer then we could use this to increase the value of your donation by using a Gift Aid form. Please request one before making your donation.

If you would like to make a regular donation we will be pleased to supply you with a standing order mandate.

 - and thank you very much for your kindness.

Stockportwithout Abuse is a Registered Charity No.1079291 and a Charitable Company Limited by Guarantee: No. 3890735

name: Street League
shortDescription: We support unemployed 16-24 year olds to move into sustained employment using the power of sport in 50 locations in England and Scotland.
description:
We engage young people through the Power of Sport.

Sport teaches teamwork, leadership, discipline and competitive spirit – not only beneficial on the pitch or in the dance studio, but also essential for the world of work.

At Street League we deliver employability services held together by the power of sport, offering a growing range of activities designed to appeal to different groups of disadvantaged young people.

Sport is integral to making Street League work – it brings people together, enables them to feel physically and mentally healthier, teaches key skills like discipline, communication and team work, and is one of the most powerful engagement tools when working with hard to reach young people.

Whether it’s through the power of football or dance fitness, we are focussed on helping our young people achieve sustainable change in their lives. We strive to be efficient and effective in everything we do, ambitious for Street League to continue to grow and have an even greater impact in eradicating youth unemployment.

Young people come to Street League in various ways, referred by unemployment offices and other social services outlets, youth workers, the probation service, through word of mouth, or via our online social media channels and refer-a-friend schemes.

During this time our staff develop a relationship with the young people and begin to talk about their aspirations with the intention, when an individual is ready, to join an Academy course. This process lasts approximately two months and although classroom-based, sport remains an integral part, and gives ‘students’ the skills and support they need to progress into education, training or work, with the support of Street League.

name: Back On Track
shortDescription: Enabling disadvantaged adults to make lasting positive changes
description: Back on Track is a Manchester charity that enables disadvantaged adults to make lasting, positive changes in their lives.  Formed in 1977, today we run a learning centre in Manchester’s Northern Quarter. We work with adults who are going through a process of recovery or rehabilitation, having been through problems with alcohol or drugs, offending, homelessness and mental health. Our projects enable people to build the skills they need to lead meaningful and fulfilling lives.

name: Step Change
shortDescription: Our team of debt experts help over 500,000 people a year across the UK to overcome their debt problems, and get their lives back on track.
description:
Here's how we can help you.We're experts in helping people to
manage and repay their debts.
We offer tailored advice and practical solutions to
help you manage debt and make a fresh start.

name: Citizens Advice Stockport
shortDescription: Citizens Advice Stockport offers free, confidential, independent, and impartial advice and information to the residents of Stockport District.
description:
The Citizens Advice service (formed in 1939) values diversity, promotes equality and challenges discrimination.

We can help with housing and employment issues or deal with queries about consumer or tax problems. We can advise on legal matters, answer questions about immigration and we have lots of experience on family and personal matters too. We are uniquely places to support our clients with any problem they face.

Citizens Advice Stockport is an independent, not-for-profit charity, supported by a range of different organisation, volunteers and paid staff without whom we would not be able to offer the quality service we do.

name: Early Break
shortDescription: Charity offering free information, advice and support for young people and families with substance misuse related issues
description:
Welcome to Early Break. We are a charity with strong roots in Bury and Rochdale but also work in surrounding areas. Established in 1994, we are a young person and families service which historically offered specialist substance misuse services. Today, we offer a wide variety of services to address all the needs of the young people and families that we support.

Early Break’s work is rooted in ‘person-centred’ theory. What this means is that the young people and families are at the centre of everything we do. Each young person sets their own goals and targets and the role of their individual worker is that they support them to achieve these goals.

name: Citizen Advice Wigan
shortDescription: Citizens Advice Manchester offers free, confidential, impartial and independent advice and information on a wide range of subjects, including housing.
description:
Every local Citizens Advice is a registered charity; we rely on trained volunteers to help provide our wide range of services.

The service is composed of the national membership organisation, Citizens Advice, and individual independent members of the network. We have the commitment and initiative to respond to the community needs of the local community, whilst benefitting from being part of a national network.

name: Calico Group
shortDescription: Innovative charities and businesses working together to make social profit, the driving force behind our wide range of high quality services.
description:
The Calico Group: innovative charities and businesses working together to make social profit, rather than financial profit, the driving force behind our wide range of high quality services.

We define “social profit” as the positive difference we make to people’s lives, across all the communities in which we work.

We create social profit by developing innovative services, and harnessing the opportunities of our unique group structure.

We’re bringing different parts of our group together for maximum social impact – We can combine our growing range of complementary services to create innovative, new opportunities for the benefit of the community.
We’re harnessing the strengths of our unique group structure – The Calico Group brings together the widest possible range of expertise: from our motivated service users, to our stakeholders who come from commercial, public and not-for-profit sectors.

We’re succeeding within private and public markets – Working together, the Calico Group delivers cost-effective, sustainable services, with profits returning to the communities we serve.
